column6:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below $10 a day.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2021 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in living costs between countries.

Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income (measured after taxes and benefits) or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.
column8: World Bank (2025). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20250930_2021 and 20250930_2017) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
Number of people living in households with an income per person below $10 a day.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2021 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in living costs between countries.

The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
Number of people living in households with an consumption per person below $10 a day.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2021 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in living costs between countries.

The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below $20 a day.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2021 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in living costs between countries.

Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income (measured after taxes and benefits) or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.
column8: World Bank (2025). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20250930_2021 and 20250930_2017) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below $20 a day.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2021 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in living costs between countries.

Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income (measured after taxes and benefits) or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.
column8: World Bank (2025). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20250930_2021 and 20250930_2017) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
Number of people living in households with an income per person below $20 a day.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2021 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in living costs between countries.

The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
Number of people living in households with an consumption per person below $20 a day.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2021 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in living costs between countries.

The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below $40 a day.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2021 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in living costs between countries.

Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income (measured after taxes and benefits) or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column8: World Bank (2025). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20250930_2021 and 20250930_2017) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
Number of people living in households with an income per person below $40 a day.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2021 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in living costs between countries.

The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.
column8: World Bank (2025). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20250930_2021 and 20250930_2017) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
Number of people living in households with an consumption per person below $40 a day.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2021 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in living costs between countries.

The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
% of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below 40% of the median.

This is a measure of _relative_ poverty – it captures the share of people whose income is low by the standards typical in their own country.

Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income (measured after taxes and benefits) or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

% of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below 40% of the median.

This is a measure of _relative_ poverty – it captures the share of people whose income is low by the standards typical in their own country.

Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income (measured after taxes and benefits) or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

This is a measure of _relative_ poverty – it captures the share of people whose income is low by the standards typical in their own country.

The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.
column8: World Bank (2025). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20250930_2021 and 20250930_2017) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
% of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below 50% of the median.

This is a measure of _relative_ poverty – it captures the share of people whose income is low by the standards typical in their own country.

Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income (measured after taxes and benefits) or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
% of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below 50% of the median.

This is a measure of _relative_ poverty – it captures the share of people whose income is low by the standards typical in their own country.

Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income (measured after taxes and benefits) or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
% of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below 60% of the median.

This is a measure of _relative_ poverty – it captures the share of people whose income is low by the standards typical in their own country.

Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income (measured after taxes and benefits) or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
% of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below 60% of the median.

This is a measure of _relative_ poverty – it captures the share of people whose income is low by the standards typical in their own country.

Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income (measured after taxes and benefits) or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.
column8: World Bank (2025). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20250930_2021 and 20250930_2017) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
% of population living in households with an income per person below 60% of the median.

This is a measure of _relative_ poverty – it captures the share of people whose income is low by the standards typical in their own country.

The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below 40% of the median.

This is a measure of _relative_ poverty – it captures the share of people whose income is low by the standards typical in their own country.

Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income (measured after taxes and benefits) or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column6:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below 40% of the median.

This is a measure of _relative_ poverty – it captures the share of people whose income is low by the standards typical in their own country.

Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income (measured after taxes and benefits) or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.
column8: World Bank (2025). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20250930_2021 and 20250930_2017) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
Number of people living in households with an income per person below 40% of the median.

This is a measure of _relative_ poverty – it captures the share of people whose income is low by the standards typical in their own country.

The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
Number of people living in households with an consumption per person below 40% of the median.

This is a measure of _relative_ poverty – it captures the share of people whose income is low by the standards typical in their own country.

The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below 50% of the median.

This is a measure of _relative_ poverty – it captures the share of people whose income is low by the standards typical in their own country.

Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income (measured after taxes and benefits) or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
Number of people living in households with an income per person below 50% of the median.

This is a measure of _relative_ poverty – it captures the share of people whose income is low by the standards typical in their own country.

The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
Number of people living in households with an consumption per person below 50% of the median.

This is a measure of _relative_ poverty – it captures the share of people whose income is low by the standards typical in their own country.

The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
Number of people living in households with an income per person below 60% of the median.

This is a measure of _relative_ poverty – it captures the share of people whose income is low by the standards typical in their own country.

The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column8: World Bank (2025). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20250930_2021 and 20250930_2017) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
Number of people living in households with an consumption per person below 60% of the median.

This is a measure of _relative_ poverty – it captures the share of people whose income is low by the standards typical in their own country.

The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
The mean level of income per day.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2021 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in living costs between countries.

The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
The mean level of consumption per day.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2021 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in living costs between countries.

The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
The level of income or consumption per day below which half of the population live.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2021 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in living costs between countries.

Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income (measured after taxes and benefits) or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column8: World Bank (2025). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20250930_2021 and 20250930_2017) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
The level of income per day below which half of the population live.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2021 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in living costs between countries.

The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

The level of consumption per day below which half of the population live.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2021 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in living costs between countries.

The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.
column8: World Bank (2025). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20250930_2021 and 20250930_2017) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
The level of income or consumption per day below which 10% of the population falls.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2021 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in living costs between countries.

Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income (measured after taxes and benefits) or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income (measured after taxes and benefits) or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.

column8: World Bank (2025). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20250930_2021 and 20250930_2017) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2025)
column6:
The level of income per day below which 10% of the population falls.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2021 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in living costs between countries.

The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

Regional and global estimates are extrapolated up until the year of the data release using GDP growth estimates and forecasts. For more details about the methodology, please refer to the [World Bank PIP documentation](https://datanalytics.worldbank.org/PIP-Methodology/lineupestimates.html#nowcasts).

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

For most countries in the PIP dataset, estimates relate to _either_ disposable income or consumption, for all available years. A number of countries, however, have a mix of income and consumption data points, with both data types sometimes available for particular years.

In most of our charts, we present the data with some data points dropped in order to present single series for each country. This allows us to make readable visualizations that combine multiple countries and metrics. In choosing which data points to drop, we try to strike a balance between maintaining comparability over time and showing as long a time series as possible. As such, the exact approach varies somewhat across countries.

If you would like to see the original data with _all_ available income and consumption data points shown separately, you can do so by selecting _Income surveys only_ or _Consumption surveys only_ in the Household survey data type dropdown or by clicking on _Show breaks between less comparable surveys_.
